title: INFANTRY OFFICER
description: Leading, supervising and evaluating Marines in the training of warfighting skills and during combat operations. Responsible for accurately collating readiness reports and briefing the status of the command’s readiness to commanding/general officers. Organizing and supervising events and displays demonstrating Marine Corps capabilities for local officials, politicians and General officers. Worked in diplomatic arenas coordinating actions between Marine units and Department of State officials while managing 149 Marine Security Guard Detachments around the world with American Embassies abroad. In charge of two unit level schools (Regimental Schools for 3rd Marine Regiment and Marine Security Guard School), overseeing daily operations, curriculum reviews and student performances. Coordinating multiple day command level conferences with several briefing participants and have coordinated projects with military officers and civilian contractors. As an Action Officer for the Secretary of the Navy’s Award Board, performed detailed administrative duties, conducted in-depth research of veteran and current combat award submissions, provided executive level summaries of significant individual actions and highlighted points of interest that would establish a basis for decisions at senior executive levels. I currently coordinate sourcing requirements for service level operations and deployments on the staff of a senior executive level command in the Marine Corps. I conduct coordination with several geographically dispersed command representatives which is conducted through video, phone and email commutations, summarizing results in briefs to senior leader and drafting official messages for service wide dissemination. I have also led and provided several periods of classroom and on-site instruction of historic military battles of the Revolutionary and Civil Wars.

title: Doctoral Student
description: My body of work for the Doctorate of Management Degree with a concentration in Organizational Development Change (ODC) and Program Management focused on the following four-year activities: (1) Theoretical research, focused on organizational development; (2) organizational leadership; (3) developing and executing organizational level business management frameworks and (4) successful defense of my practitioner’s dissertation before a three member committee from the Colorado Technical University in ~Dec 2010. The 1st year focused on for theoretical, classic and current organizational and program management literature research. The 2nd year focused on course work and practitioner application of my evolving management frameworks that analyzed and applied program and process improvement methods used in Organizational Development, Change Management and Business Capture Management. The 3rd and 4th years focused on my development and execution of organizational level business management frameworks that evaluated my ability to implement, manage measure and execute program / business process improvement activities.

title: Senior Army Officer
company: US Army (Military Intelligence, Infantry, Military Police)
description: Progressed through multiple vital military intelligence, Infantry and Military Police positions throughout highly successful 22-year Army career. Directed collection, analysis and distribution of critical national intelligence data. Assembled, trained and directed teams of top-notch all-source intelligence gathering analysts and Information Technology (IT) professionals who performed the collection analysis and reporting of classified C4ISR data to national and international government DOD, and civilian agencies. Reported regularly to senior-level Military and Civilian decision makers on status of critical intelligence initiatives vital to the U.S. national defense. Key Achievements: 1. Orchestrated planning and initiation of multiple strategic, operational and tactical Military Intelligence gathering procedures. 2. Drove design, development and upkeep of secured international, national, regional internet for uploading and access of critical intelligence data by over 12,000 users. 3. Led operational intelligence gathering and reporting mission for a combined JOINT organization of over 500 U.S. and NATO personnel conducting real-time critical operational rest of world signal and imagery intelligence collection, analysis and exploitation missions in support of the Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA) Shared Production Program. 4. Led and managed an operational organization of 150 military and DoD civilian personnel performing IT service support activities and equipment maintenance/turn-in procedures for approximately $500 million dollars worth of automated data processing (ADP) and satellite equipment used to perform real-time operational signal and imagery processing, exploitation and dissemination activities.

title: Assistant Professor of German
description: Assistant Professor and Course Director of Advance German Through the Media and Basic German Courses I: • Formulated lesson plans and implements pedagogical approaches, methods, and techniques for formal and computer-based foreign language learning and/or second-language acquisition (SLA). • Prepared and presented daily and remedial German foreign language instruction, wrote, administered and monitored quizzes/examinations, and reported student progress as part of West Point’s applied linguistics language education program. • Served as the Officer-in-Charge (OIC) of the German Academic Individual Advance Development Program, German Foreign Academy Exchange Program, and Cadet Extra-curricular Club that supports the academy’s goals of improving the West Point racial environment. Key Achievements: • Researched, analyzed, developed, wrote and executed functional (requesting something), interactive (social) and structured (e.g., grammar) foreign language pedagogical methods and innovative integrated computer-based technologies that: (1) determined impacts and benefits for developing lesson plans; (2) integrated appropriate language training/learning technologies; and (3) prepared estimates of requirements for manpower, equipment, supplies, services, pedagogical training and/or travel funding for staff who supported student-based German SLA activities. • Enabled 50 cadets, over 3-year period, to experience 3 weeks in Germany with German military unit or government organizations by managing state-of-the-art, total immersion German Capstone language program comprised of improved pedagogy and Internet/social media technology. • Supervised 6 senior German language instructors teaching 14 class sections with 250 students, total. • Increased junior and senior enrollment over 2-year period through redesigning course curriculum with focus on computer language technology and use of Internet for advanced language acquisition.
